_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Executive Summary briefly reviews the major elements of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for One Earth Energy, LLCs (One Earth) dry mill ethanol production facility located in Gibson City, IL. This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR 68) and Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. The One Earth ethanol facility is subject to the RMP rule due to the storage of natural gasoline (denaturant), a regulated flammable mixture, above the respective threshold quantity.  This RMP submittal is to meet the five (5) year submission requirements of the EPA Title 40 Part 68 requirements for the facility.

1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
 
One Earth is committed to protecting the environment and operating facilities in a manner that promotes the safety of employees and the public. Management has adopted and implemented policies that adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations. The design and construction of the facility has incorporated physical and operational safeguards to prevent accidental releases. Through the proper design, installation, operation and maintenance of the equipment, and the training of our personnel, One Earth has minimized the hazard to human health and the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudden release of hazardous materials.  

In the event that a release does occur, the facilitys emergency response actions are described in its Emergency Action Plan (EAP). The EAP includes procedures to coordinate response actions with local emergency response personnel (i.e., law enforcement, fire, and rescue departments, emergency medical services, hospital, and government personnel, etc.) as well as any potentially affected neighbors.  In addition, the EAP is used to familiarize local emergency response personnel with the types of materials h

andled and One Earths emergency response procedures.

2.	Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

The One Earth facility is a 150 million gallon per year corn-based dry-mill denatured ethanol fuel production facility. Ethanol is produced through the conversion of corn starch to sugars and then conversion of the sugars to ethanol (i.e., grain alcohol) through a continuous fermentation and distillation process. 

Regulated substances stored at the facility include natural gasoline, which is used as a denaturant in the ethanol fuel product.

3.	Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

One Earth has programs in place to address accidental release prevention measures required by EPA, Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and notification requirements of EPA's Emergency Response and Community Right-to-Know regulations. The facility complies with PSM for the management of ethanol and natural gasoline (denaturant).



Employee Participation

One Earth has developed an employee participation program. All process safety information, process hazard analysis (PHA) results, recommendations, action items, incident investigations, compliance audits, operating procedures, emergency response plan, and records of management of change are available to the operating personnel at any time.

Process Hazard Analysis and Process Safety Information

The facility utilizes the HAZOP PHA methodology in the analytical review of the regulated process. The PHA has identified the following potential major hazards: fire, explosion, over-pressurization, corrosion, over-filling and equipment failure. The facility utilizes process controls such as vents, relief valves, check valves, manual shutoffs, automatic shutoffs, interlocks, alarms and procedures, grounding equipment, and preventative maintenance activities to prevent or limit releases.  

One Earth keeps a variety of technic

al documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the facility. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs). The facility also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, pressure relief design and calculations, and piping and instrumentation drawings.

Operating Procedures and Training

One Earth maintains written procedures that address all modes of process operations, including normal operations, manual operation, regeneration, and emergency shutdown.  The facility has developed and implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in facility operations.  

Contractors

The contractor safety procedures establish minimum guidelines and activities to assure that the contractor's employees follow safe work practices and procedures. The procedure includes a contractor screening process and hazard awareness, safety and emergency procedures training. All contractors performing work on or near a covered process are required to undergo Contractor Qualification prior to acceptance as a contractor to perform work at the facility.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

One Earth performs a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.

Mechanical Integrity

The facilitys mechanical integrity program includes written procedures, training, task and testing schedules, equipment design and installation information, and regular inspections and equipment testing procedures to maintain

pressure vessels, piping systems, relief systems, pumps, emergency shutdown systems, and controls in a safe operating condition.  

Management of Change

The facilitys Management of Change (MOC) program reviews all proposed changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, materials, and design conditions prior to implementation of the change. Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by a process change.  

Incident Investigation

One Earth has procedures to promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in or could reasonably result in a release of an RMP regulated substance. The procedure establishes the minimum guidelines and activities of the incident investigation program to reduce the likelihood of repetitive occurrences of events which could reasonably lead to catastrophic releases. Investigations will be undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a similar release in the future.

Compliance Audits

The facility performs regular compliance audits of the provisions of RMP to verify that procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed. The audit includes a review of documentation and process safety information, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel.

4.	  Accident History

The facility has not had any accidents reportable under RMP since start-up of facility operations. 


5.	Emergency Response Program

One Earth maintains a written Emergency Action Plan (EAP). The intent of the EAP is to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The EAP addresses aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencie

s and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, One Earth has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. One Earth works with the local fire department and emergency responders to ensure the proper execution of our plan. The Emergency Action Plan is updated, when necessary, based on modifications made to facility processes, management practices, and/or procedures.

6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The One Earth facility has been designed and constructed to meet existing construction and process safety requirements. One Earth will continue to evaluate and implement changes as necessary to improve safety at the facility.
